section.title: The FPF and HTML Entities
section.p: As the FPF parsed xhtml code as valid XML it does not like HTML entities such as &nbsp, &copy and the like, so they should be avoided. The general recommendation is to serve your pages with an UTF-8 charset that eliminates the need for most of those entities as they are just valid chars. So instead of &copy use the regular Â© sign. For all other entities that don't have a character to display use the numeric entities - instead of   use &160;. Numeric entities parse just fine in XML.
An alternative way would be to add all entities you use to a local DTD or to use the HTML parsing mode, but those have their own drawbacks.
